fields.Title of Presentation: Love, Motherhood and Mortality in Circe
fields.Conference/Meeting Name: National Endowment for the Arts Big Read Event- was paid 300$ honorarium
fields.Description/Abstract:
My brief talk and longer discussion will focus on Madeline Miller’s recent novel, Circe. Circle reimagines the story of a minor goddess and sorceress best known for turning sailors into pigs and having an affair with Odysseus in The Odyssey. Circe also plays a minor role in myths about the Minotaur’s origins and Jason and the Golden Fleece. Claire Messud describes Miller’s novel as a “highly psychologized, redemptive and ultimately exculpatory account” of Circe’s adventures. Miller’s Circe begins life as an overlooked child, grows into a petulant teenager, and then matures into a loving mother of her son by Odysseus. Not only is Miler’s novel a feminist revision of myth and epic, but it's also just a great story. As Massud writes, like a “good children’s book, it engrosses and races along at a clip, eliciting excitement and emotion along the way.” My talk and the discussion afterward will explore what happens when stories focusing on men’s greatness get retold from a female perspective.
 
Claire Messud quotations from Review of Circe: “New York Times” May 28, 2018
